recipes.title: Eggplant 'Tyeshin Yazyk'
recipes.story:
In its original, more high maintenance incarnation, this eggplant appetizer can be made as rolls from long, elegant Chinese eggplants—thin slices curled up with a sharp garlicky sauce and crowned with tomatoes, like little canapés for a cocktail party.

In our version, the drama stays but the labor doesn’t: we swap in sturdy, bulbous globe eggplants, cut them into slim rounds, and stack everything flat. Same ‘mother in law’s tongue’ attitude, far less emotional (and culinary) effort.

ingredients.name: large Chinese or bulbous globe eggplants (1 lb)

instructions.title: Prep eggplants
instructions.text: Cut off stems and slice eggplants into 0.5 inch rounds. Lay on baking sheet.

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Brush with olive oil, sprinkle generously with salt and pepper.

instructions.title: Roast
instructions.text: Roast for 50–60 minutes in preheated oven at 400°F.

instructions.title: Make sauce
instructions.text: Meanwhile, mince garlic and mix with mayonnaise or Greek yogurt.

instructions.title: Assemble
instructions.text: Spread thin layer of mayo sauce over roasted eggplants.

instructions.title: Top
instructions.text: Slice tomatoes and assemble on top of eggplants.

tips: For egg-free option, use Greek yogurt with salt instead of mayo
Can be made in advance and refrigerated for a couple of days
Garnish with parsley, dill or cilantro
recipes.culturalBackground: The name “Tyeshin Yazyk” literally means “mother in law’s tongue” in Russian—a playful nod to the dish’s sharp, garlicky bite and slightly dramatic personality. This style of eggplant appetizer is part of the Slavic zakuski tradition, the cold and warm bites that cover the table before a big feast, where families turned humble vegetables into elegant small plates for entertaining. Variations of “mother in law’s tongue”—layers of fried eggplant, garlic sauce, and tomatoes—show up across post Soviet kitchens from Russia and Ukraine to Central Asia, a familiar sight at holiday tables and family celebrations. Across the Caucasus, eggplant appetizers take on even more ornate forms: Georgian and Armenian cooks roll thin slices around a fragrant walnut garlic paste and finish them with ruby pomegranate seeds, badrijani style cousins that share the same festive spirit—humble ingredients turned into a richly layered, celebration table ritual.

recipes.story: A staple in southern Central Asia with Uzbek, Uyghur, and Chinese variations. Found in countless cafes across the region.

ingredients.name: tomato or Turkish sweet pepper paste

instructions.text: Cut meat into small-medium cubes. Wash and cut vegetables: onions/carrots/daikon into strings, bell pepper/tomatoes/potatoes into cubes.

instructions.title: Brown meat

instructions.title: Finish

recipes.title: Avgolemono
recipes.story: Greek lemon-egg soup with orzo – bright and comforting.

instructions.title: Broth
instructions.text: Boil water, add bones, simmer 2 hrs (or pressure cook 10-15 hrs).

instructions.title: Orzo
instructions.text: When stock is ready, add orzo and cook until tender.

instructions.title: Egg mixture
instructions.text: Beat eggs until frothy. Add salt/pepper.

instructions.title: Temper eggs
instructions.text: Gradually add 1 cup hot broth to eggs by spoonfuls, whisking constantly.

instructions.title: Combine
instructions.text: Pour egg mixture back into pot, stirring constantly over very low heat.

instructions.title: Finish
instructions.text: Add lemon juice last to prevent curdling. Stir gently.

tips: Turkey bones give richer flavor than chicken. Sub orzo with white rice. Use chicken feet with bones for extra gelatin.

recipes.title: Herring Under Fur
recipes.story: Layered 'dressed herring' salad with beets, potatoes, carrots, eggs, onions, and herring – another New Year symbol in post-Soviet countries.

ingredients.name: potatoes, medium, boiled with skin on

instructions.title: Roast beets
instructions.text: Wrap beets snugly in foil and roast about 100 min at 400°F until soft and tender. Cool, then peel.

instructions.title: Cook vegetables and eggs
instructions.text: Boil potatoes and carrots 20-30 min until cooked but firm; cool and peel. Hard-boil eggs and peel.

instructions.title: Grate and chop
instructions.text: Grate potatoes, carrots, beets, and eggs into separate bowls. Finely chop onion and herring separately.

instructions.title: Layer salad
instructions.text: On a serving plate, create layers in this order: herring, onions, potatoes (spread with a thin layer of mayonnaise), carrots, eggs (add another thin layer of mayonnaise), and beets on top. Repeat layers if desired.

instructions.title: Finish
instructions.text: Smooth the top layer of beets and decorate with chopped dill or parsley. Chill before serving.

tips: Roasted beets give deeper flavor than boiled.
Do not overcook potatoes and carrots.
For a molded look, you can assemble in reverse order in a bowl and flip onto a serving plate.

instructions.title: Mix

tips: Roasted beets have a sweeter, deeper flavor than boiled.

Adjust garlic and yogurt-to-mayo ratio to taste.

recipes.title: Beshbarmak
recipes.story: Traditional Kazakh feast dish of tender meat, dough sheets, and rich onion sauce. Similar meat-and-pasta traditions appear in Southern European cuisines too.

ingredients.name: meat (beef and lamb, preferably on the bone)

instructions.title: Cook broth
instructions.text: Bring water to a boil in a deep saucepan. Add meat and whole tomato; water should cover meat and bones. Once it returns to a boil, reduce heat immediately and skim foam. Simmer 2 hours until meat is tender.

instructions.title: Alternative broth
instructions.text: As an easier option, place cold water, meat, and tomato in a pressure cooker on slow-cook for 10–15 hours. Skim foam once cooking is finished.

instructions.title: Cook potatoes
instructions.text: Remove meat from broth. Add peeled, halved potatoes and cook in the broth 20–30 minutes until tender. Remove potatoes to a separate bowl.

instructions.title: Make dough
instructions.text: Combine flour, 1 Tbsp salt, egg, and 0.5 cup water into a firm dough. Knead until smooth, rest 20–30 minutes, then roll into thin sheets and cut into large rectangles.

instructions.title: Cook dough in broth
instructions.text: Cook the dough sheets (or lasagna sheets) briefly in the hot broth until just tender. Remove and drain.

instructions.title: Tusdyk (sauce)
instructions.text: In a separate saucepan, slice onions into half-rings, chop leeks and carrots. Add black pepper and bay leaves. Pour in about 2 cups of broth and simmer 10 minutes until vegetables soften.

instructions.title: Assemble
instructions.text: Slice cooked meat into pieces. On a large platter, first arrange dough sheets, then place potatoes in a circle. Put meat in the center and pour the hot onion-leek-carrot sauce over the top.

tips: Lasagna sheets work as a quick dough alternative, but homemade dough has better texture.
Use a mix of beef and lamb with bones for deeper flavor.

recipes.title: Central Asian Plov (Pilaf)
recipes.story: Classic Central Asian pilaf of meat, rice, carrots, and fragrant spices—perfect for feeding a crowd.

ingredients.name: boneless beef (or beef with some bone)

instructions.title: Prep rice and vegetables
instructions.text: Rinse rice under running water until clear, then soak in cold water. Cut meat into matchbox-sized pieces. Cut carrots into 0.5×0.5 cm sticks. Slice onions into thin rings or half-rings. Clean garlic heads, removing roots and dirt, but keep heads whole.

instructions.title: Brown meat
instructions.text: Heat oil in a cauldron or Dutch oven over high heat. Deep-fry meat in 3–4 batches until golden-brown. Remove if needed between batches.

instructions.title: Cook onions and carrots
instructions.text: Add onions to the hot oil and cook until golden. Return meat, stir to prevent onions from burning. Add carrots and cook, stirring occasionally, 15–20 minutes until they start to wilt and lightly brown.

instructions.title: Season and simmer
instructions.text: Rub 2/3 of the cumin seeds between your palms to release aroma and add to the pot. Pour in hot water just to cover meat and vegetables. Add salt. Simmer 40–90 minutes (depending on meat) until most water evaporates and meat is tender. Do not stir.

instructions.title: Add rice and aromatics
instructions.text: Turn heat to high. Drain rice well and spread it evenly in one layer over the meat and vegetables. Nestle whole garlic heads and whole chilies into the rice. Carefully pour boiling water over a spoon or ladle held above the rice to avoid disturbing the layer, covering the rice by about 2 cm. Add a bit more salt so the water tastes slightly over-salted.

instructions.title: Cook rice
instructions.text: Boil rapidly until the water level drops to the surface of the rice and is absorbed; rice should be al dente. Use a spoon or chopstick to poke holes down to the bottom to check moisture and allow steam to escape.

instructions.title: Steam and finish
instructions.text: Reduce heat to very low, cover tightly, and steam 20 minutes. Turn off heat, remove garlic and chilies to a plate. Gently mix rice with meat and carrots. Adjust salt if needed and let stand 5 minutes.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.text: Pile plov on a large warmed platter. Serve with garlic heads, chilies, and a simple salad of thinly sliced tomatoes, sweet onions, chili, and salt.

tips: Use long-grain or plov-friendly rice that keeps shape.
Do not stir once rice is added; keep layers intact.
Dried fruits like apricots and raisins add a festive touch.

recipes.title: Golubtzy (Cabbage Rolls)
recipes.story: Classic cabbage rolls stuffed with savory ground beef and simmered in a tomato-based sauce.

ingredients.name: tomato paste or tomato sauce (for sofrito/zazharka)

instructions.title: Prep cabbage leaves
instructions.text: Carefully separate cabbage leaves one by one. Soak them in a bowl of hot water to soften.

instructions.title: Prepare filling
instructions.text: Use your prepared ground beef base: mix ground beef with finely chopped onion, salt, pepper, and chopped dill.

instructions.title: Make sofrito sauce
instructions.text: In a pan, sauté the second onion and grated carrot in oil until soft and golden. Stir in tomato paste or tomato sauce and cook a few minutes to develop flavor.

instructions.title: Stuff rolls
instructions.text: Place a spoonful of ground beef mixture onto each softened cabbage leaf. Roll tightly, folding in sides to form neat rolls.

instructions.title: Simmer
instructions.text: Arrange cabbage rolls snugly in a pot over the sofrito. Add enough water to partially cover the rolls. Cover and simmer gently 50–60 minutes until cabbage and filling are tender.

tips: Flat cabbage from Asian stores is easier to roll.
Trim thick veins on cabbage leaves for easier rolling.

recipes.title: Chicken Tapaka
recipes.story: Georgian-style spatchcocked chicken cooked under a heavy weight until crisp on the outside and juicy inside.

instructions.title: Flatten chicken
instructions.text: Cut the hen along the breastbone, open it like a book, and flatten on a board with a meat mallet until even and thinner.

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Rub the skin and flesh with salt.

instructions.title: Brown
instructions.text: Heat an iron skillet over medium-high and melt butter. Place chicken skin-side down and fry each side about 5 minutes until nicely browned.

instructions.title: Add garlic and water
instructions.text: Crush garlic cloves, mix with water, and pour over the chicken.

instructions.title: Cook under weight
instructions.text: Reduce heat to medium-low. Place a heavy lid or a plate with a weight on top of the chicken to press it down. Cover and cook 20 minutes on low heat until cooked through and very tender.

tips: Cover chicken with plastic wrap or wax paper before pounding to avoid splatter.
Serve with gnocchi, potatoes, or simple vegetables.
recipes.culturalBackground: From the mountainous Caucasus region, this dish embodies Georgian hospitality and the tradition of bold, aromatic flavors that have made Georgian cuisine beloved across the former Soviet Union.

recipes.title: Chicken (or Duck) in the Oven
recipes.story: Simple whole bird roasted with garlic and butter until crisp on the outside and juicy inside.

instructions.title: Prep bird
instructions.text: Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Pat the hen or duck dry with paper towels. Cut along the breast and flatten, or leave whole if preferred.

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Rub skin and cavity with salt.

instructions.title: Garlic butter
instructions.text: Crush garlic cloves and mix with softened or melted butter.

instructions.title: Roast
instructions.text: Place bird in a roasting pan. Brush with garlic butter, pour water into the bottom of the pan, and roast 50–70 minutes (depending on size), basting occasionally, until juices run clear.

tips: Cover bird with foil if skin browns too quickly.
Let rest 10–15 minutes before carving. Serve with gnocchi or potatoes.

recipes.title: Roasted Leg of Lamb
recipes.story: Festive roasted leg of lamb with simple seasoning—perfect centerpiece for a family meal.

instructions.title: Prep lamb
instructions.text: Bring lamb to room temperature 1 hour before cooking. Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Make small slits in lamb and insert slivers of garlic. Rub lamb with olive oil, salt, pepper, and herbs if using.

instructions.title: Roast
instructions.text: Place lamb in a roasting pan. Roast 20 minutes, then lower heat to 350°F (175°C) and continue roasting 15–20 minutes per pound, until desired doneness.

instructions.title: Rest
instructions.text: Remove from oven, tent with foil, and rest 15–20 minutes before carving.

tips: For medium-rare, internal temperature should reach about 135–140°F after resting.
Serve with potatoes or rice and a simple salad.

recipes.title: Beef Tongue
recipes.story: Exceptionally tender and mild-flavored, beef tongue makes an elegant appetizer served sliced and simply garnished.

instructions.title: Simmer tongue
instructions.text: Place beef tongue in a large pot, cover with water, and bring to a gentle boil. Add salt, reduce heat, and simmer 2–3 hours until very tender and a knife slides in easily.

instructions.title: Peel
instructions.text: Remove tongue from pot and let cool slightly. While still warm, peel off the tough outer skin; it should come off easily.

instructions.title: Slice and serve
instructions.text: Slice tongue across the grain into 0.5-inch pieces. Arrange on a serving plate, garnish with parsley or dill. Serve warm or at room temperature.

tips: Slow, gentle cooking is key for a delicate texture.
For a variation, drizzle with sesame oil, sprinkle sesame seeds, and serve with a splash of soy sauce.
You can cook tongue in a pressure cooker until fully tender to save time.

recipes.title: Kholodets (Meat Jelly)
recipes.story: Traditional meat jelly made from long-simmered beef feet and meat—rich, savory, and served cold in slices.

instructions.title: Soak bones
instructions.text: Soak beef feet in cold water 2–3 hours. Drain and rinse.

instructions.title: Start broth
instructions.text: Place feet in a pot, cover with water, and bring to a boil. Once it boils, discard the water. Refill with fresh water just to barely cover the meat—do not add too much or the jelly will not set. Bring to a boil again, add salt, then reduce to a gentle simmer for about 3 hours.

instructions.title: Add meat and onion
instructions.text: After 3 hours, add beef fillet and whole unpeeled onion. Simmer together another 1.5 hours.

instructions.title: Add vegetables
instructions.text: Add whole carrots and celery root. Cook until vegetables are tender.

instructions.title: Prepare meat
instructions.text: Remove meat and bones. Separate meat from bones and cut into small pieces. Return meat pieces to the broth.

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Add black pepper and bay leaves and simmer 5–10 minutes. Skim off excess fat from the surface.

instructions.title: Finish and set
instructions.text: Grate the whole garlic bulb and chop cilantro or parsley. Stir into hot broth with meat. Remove bay leaves. Pour into molds or dishes and let cool; refrigerate until fully set.

tips: The broth should be rich and concentrated; too much water will prevent it from setting.
Serve cold, sliced, with mustard or horseradish if desired.

recipes.title: Beef Liver with Onions, Garlic & Balsamic Glaze
recipes.story: Highly nutritious and rich in iron, this beef liver is soaked, quickly sautéed, and finished with a touch of balsamic glaze.

instructions.title: Prep liver
instructions.text: Remove the thin membrane from the liver. Soak liver in milk about 30 minutes to tenderize and reduce bitterness.

instructions.title: Season
instructions.text: Pat liver dry, slice into pieces if needed, and season lightly with salt and pepper. Let sit a few minutes.

instructions.title: Sauté aromatics
instructions.text: Slice onion and mince garlic. In a frying pan, heat olive oil over medium heat and sauté onions and garlic until soft and fragrant.

instructions.title: Cook liver
instructions.text: Add liver pieces to the pan, lower heat, and cook gently about 5 minutes, just until cooked through. Do not overcook—liver should stay tender.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.text: Transfer to a plate and lightly drizzle with balsamic glaze.

tips: Removing the membrane and soaking in milk are key to tenderness and mild flavor.
The biggest secret is short, gentle cooking; overcooked liver becomes tough.
Serve immediately for best texture.
recipes.culturalBackground: This dish represents the rich culinary heritage of Central Asia, where nomadic traditions met Silk Road influences to create unique and flavorful recipes passed down through generations.

recipes.title: Baursak (Kazakh Puffy Bread)
recipes.story: Traditional Kazakh puffy fried dough, often served with tea during holidays and family gatherings.

instructions.title: Make dough
instructions.text: Combine flour, yeast, warm water, egg, butter, sugar, and salt in a large bowl to form a soft dough.

instructions.title: Knead and rise
instructions.text: Knead dough on a floured surface until smooth. Return to bowl, cover with a towel, and let rise about 30 minutes.

instructions.title: Heat oil
instructions.text: Heat vegetable oil in a deep skillet over high or medium-high heat.

instructions.title: Shape
instructions.text: Pinch off tablespoon-sized pieces of dough and roll into balls. Press down slightly.

instructions.title: Fry
instructions.text: Carefully drop dough pieces into hot oil and fry until golden brown on all sides. Drain on paper towels.

tips: Serve warm with Kazakh chai, honey, or a sprinkle of sugar.
Do not overcrowd the pan; fry in batches for even browning.
recipes.culturalBackground: This dish represents the rich culinary heritage of Central Asia, where nomadic traditions met Silk Road influences to create unique and flavorful recipes passed down through generations.

recipes.title: Blintchiki (Crepes)
recipes.story: Thin, tender crepes perfect for breakfast or dessert, ready to fill with jam, cheese, or sour cream.

instructions.title: Start batter
instructions.text: In a bowl whisk eggs with sugar and salt. Add 1 cup of milk and mix well.

instructions.title: Combine dry ingredients
instructions.text: In a separate bowl mix flour and baking powder. Gradually whisk dry ingredients into the egg mixture, alternating with the remaining milk and water until smooth.

instructions.title: Finish batter
instructions.text: Stir in vanilla, cognac or whiskey, and olive oil. Batter should be thin and pourable.

instructions.title: Cook crepes
instructions.text: Heat a 12-inch nonstick skillet over medium heat and lightly coat with butter. Pour in a small amount of batter, swirling to cover the bottom. Cook 2–3 minutes until underside is golden.

instructions.title: Flip
instructions.text: Loosen edge with a spatula and flip. Cook 1–2 minutes more. Transfer to a plate, spread with a thin layer of butter, and cover with a lid while you cook remaining crepes, buttering the pan as needed.

tips: Let batter rest 10–15 minutes if you have time for more tender crepes.
Adjust with a splash of milk or water if batter becomes too thick.
recipes.culturalBackground: A classic from Russian and Soviet-era home cooking, this dish showcases the resourcefulness and hospitality that defined family gatherings across the former USSR.

recipes.title: Börek with Feta & Greens
recipes.story: Savory layered filo pie filled with feta, spinach, and herbs—perfect for brunch or as a light main.

instructions.title: Soak feta
instructions.text: Soak feta cheese in cold water 25–30 minutes to remove excess salt, then drain and crumble.

instructions.title: Make filling
instructions.text: Chop spinach and parsley. Mix with egg, sour cream, and crumbled feta to form the filling.

instructions.title: Butter mixture
instructions.text: In a separate bowl melt butter and mix with milk.

instructions.title: Layer filo
instructions.text: Preheat oven to 360°F (180°C). Brush a baking pan with butter-milk mixture. Lay down half of the filo sheets one by one, brushing each sheet lightly with the butter-milk mixture.

instructions.title: Add filling
instructions.text: Spread the filling evenly over the layered filo. Cover with remaining filo sheets, brushing each with butter-milk mixture.

instructions.title: Score and bake
instructions.text: Pre-cut the top into pieces with a sharp knife. Bake 40 minutes at 360°F, then reduce to 280°F (140°C) and bake 10 minutes more.

tips: Keep filo sheets covered with a damp towel while working so they do not dry out.
Let börek rest 10–15 minutes before cutting to keep layers intact.
recipes.culturalBackground: Rooted in Mediterranean tradition, this recipe celebrates the region's emphasis on fresh vegetables, olive oil, and simple preparations that let quality ingredients shine.

recipes.title: Cake Tvorozhniy
recipes.story: Soft vanilla cake with a tangy tvorog/ricotta topping—simple, tender, and perfect with tea.

instructions.title: Activate soda
instructions.text: Mix buttermilk and baking soda in a bowl. Let rest 10 minutes.

instructions.title: Egg mixture
instructions.text: In a second bowl whisk egg with 2/3 cup sugar and vanilla.

instructions.title: Combine wet
instructions.text: Combine the buttermilk mixture with the egg mixture. Add vegetable oil and stir until smooth.

instructions.title: Add dry
instructions.text: In a third bowl mix flour and baking powder. Gently fold dry ingredients into wet until just combined.

instructions.title: Prepare topping
instructions.text: In a small bowl whisk 1 egg with ricotta (or twarog) and 3 Tbsp sugar until smooth.

instructions.title: Bake
instructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Pour batter into a greased pan. Spoon or spread the cheese topping over the batter. Bake 30–40 minutes, until a toothpick in the cake (not topping) comes out clean.

tips: Let cake cool slightly before slicing so topping can set.
Use well-drained ricotta/twarog so the topping is not too runny.
recipes.culturalBackground: A testament to Eastern European home baking traditions, this recipe showcases the region's love for sweet, comforting desserts that bring families together.

recipes.title: Apricot Pie
recipes.story:
Moist apricot cake soaked with a sweet sour-cream glaze—an old-fashioned teacake-style dessert that somehow held its own on a very serious Eid table in our semi-desert corner of central Kazakhstan, crowded with meat dishes, salads, and every imaginable side.

After the main feast, when the dessert platters finally appeared, our mom’s three or four “simple” apricot pies for about 30 guests were always the first to vanish, quietly stealing the spotlight from everything else on the table.

instructions.title: Make batter
instructions.text: Mix eggs, 1 cup sugar, and vanilla with melted butter until smooth.

instructions.title: Add dry
instructions.text: Mix baking powder with flour and fold into the batter until just combined.

instructions.title: Layer apricots
instructions.text: Preheat oven to 380–390°F (depending on your oven size; larger ovens may require the higher temperature). Lightly grease a baking pan and arrange half of the apricots on the bottom, then place the remaining apricots on top.

instructions.title: Bake cake
instructions.text: Pour batter over the apricots. Arrange remaining apricots on top and let them sink slightly. Bake 40 minutes at 380°F, then lower to 340°F (170°C) and bake another 40 minutes.

instructions.title: Sour-cream glaze
instructions.text: Mix sour cream with 1/2 cup sugar until smooth. Pour over the warm cake in an even layer and return to the oven for 10 minutes.

tips: Cool before slicing so the glaze can set.
Use good-quality jarred apricots in light syrup for best flavor.
recipes.culturalBackground: This moist teacake embodies the Eastern European tradition of transforming preserved fruits into elegant desserts. The sour cream glaze technique was perfected in Soviet-era home baking, where resourceful cooks created luxurious treats from simple pantry staples.

recipes.title: Tchak-tchak
recipes.story: Crispy fried dough pieces coated in honey or caramel-like syrup, a beloved Tatar dessert often served at celebrations.

instructions.title: Make dough
instructions.text: Beat eggs with sugar, salt, milk, and vodka/cognac. Add baking powder and enough flour to make a soft, pliable dough. Cover and rest 1 hour.

instructions.title: Shape
instructions.text: Roll out dough very thin and cut into small thin strips or pieces.

instructions.title: Fry
instructions.text: Heat oil in a saucepan. Fry dough pieces in small batches until golden, usually under 1 minute. Drain on paper towels.

instructions.title: Add nuts
instructions.text: Grind or chop walnuts (and pecans if using) and mix with the fried dough pieces in a large bowl.

instructions.title: Make syrup (choose one option)
instructions.text: For honey syrup: gently heat honey and sugar, stirring until sugar dissolves. For honey + dulce de leche: heat and stir together until smooth. For condensed milk: warm slightly if needed to loosen.

instructions.title: Coat and shape
instructions.text: Pour hot syrup over the fried dough and nuts. Mix carefully until evenly coated. Shape on a flat plate or in a mold and let cool. Decorate with extra pecans if desired.

tips: Work in small frying batches so pieces do not stick.
Shape while syrup is still warm; it sets as it cools.
Light alcohol in the dough helps keep pieces crisp and airy.
recipes.culturalBackground: Tchak-tchak is the crown jewel of Tatar celebrations, often served at weddings as a symbol of sweet wishes for the newlyweds. The name comes from the sound the fried dough makes when being assembled—a testament to its crispy, honey-coated texture that has delighted Central Asian families for generations.

recipes.title: Lemon Cherry Pie
recipes.story: Bright lemon-scented cake studded with cherries, apples, and crunchy pecans.

topping.name: lemon or orange peel, simmered and chopped

instructions.title: Prep peel
instructions.text: Simmer lemon or orange peel in water 10 minutes, then drain and cut into small pieces.

instructions.title: Make batter
instructions.text: Mix eggs with salt, then add brown sugar and whisk well.

instructions.title: Add flavorings
instructions.text: Stir in vanilla, liquor, and melted butter until smooth.

instructions.title: Add dry
instructions.text: Mix baking powder with flour and fold into batter until just combined.

instructions.title: Add peel
instructions.text: Stir chopped lemon/orange peel into the batter.

instructions.title: Assemble
instructions.text: Pour batter into a greased pan. Scatter frozen cherries over the top and let them sink slightly. Arrange apple slices on top and let them sink. Sprinkle with crushed pecans, if using.

instructions.title: Bake
instructions.text: Bake in a preheated oven 50 minutes at 375°F (190°C), then lower heat to 340°F (170°C) and bake another 40 minutes, until a toothpick comes out clean.

tips: Simmering the citrus peel removes bitterness and softens it.
Use frozen cherries straight from the freezer; they will sink into the batter as it bakes.
recipes.culturalBackground: This bright, fruit-studded cake represents the European tradition of celebrating citrus and stone fruits in baked goods. The addition of liquor to the batter reflects Old World baking wisdom—a small amount of alcohol enhances flavor and creates a tender crumb.
